speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, good morning, Dr. Crane.  Not a morning person, are we? Well, never you mind.  I am.  Can't very well be a good health care provider if you're not up with the cock.  I've already taken your father for his morning constitutional.  Such a remarkable man - thirty years on the police force.  I can understand why you'd want him to live here, although not many sons would do that, not without getting paid for it.  Anyway, coffee's made, and I took the liberty of doing a shop.  They don't serve much tripe in Seattle, do they?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_still groggy_] And you are...?

speaker: Daphne
text: Daphne.  Daphne Moon.  I moved in yesterday.  You hired me to take care of your father.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_realizing_] Of course.  Forgive me, I'm not quite myself until I've shaved and showered.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, yes.  I completely understand about one's morning ablutions. I, for instance, can't stand myself 'til I floss all that gunk out of my teeth...

speaker: Frasier
text: [_interrupting_] Miss Moon!  For future reference, if you could just keep your ablutions on a need-to-know basis?  Thank you. [_goes into kitchen_] Now, my coffee.

speaker: Martin
text: [_doing a fry-up_] The half 'n half's curdled, and the garbage disposal's jammed.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_pouring his coffee_] Good morning to you too, dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Morning was two hours ago.  And close that barn door, we got a lady in the house now.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hey, this isn't my coffee.  Where's my finely-ground Kenya blend from Starbucks?

speaker: Martin
text: That's it.  Daphne put an eggshell and some allspice in it.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_pouring it down the sink_] Didn't that just dress it up?

speaker: Martin
text: I like it.  Gives it a zing.  Now, come on, sit down.  Your breakfast is ready.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_following_] Oh, no, dad, dad, look, all I ever have is a bran muffin, and a touch of yogurt.

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, girlie food.  Besides, I already fixed your breakfast.  Now, I made you "Eggs in a Nest."

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah yes, the Crane family specialty.  Fried eggs swimming in fat, served in a delightfully hollowed-out piece of white bread. I can almost hear my left ventricle slamming shut as I speak.

speaker: Martin
text: You want cheese on that?

speaker: Frasier
text: No.  I'd like to leave some blood flow for the clot to go swiftly to my brain. [_to himself_] Can't have my coffee, can't have my breakfast, [_sees Martin 's chair_] Oh god, it wasn't a dream.  I'll get him for this. [_to Eddie_] And his little dog, too. [_opens front door_] Where's my paper?  Who's stolen my paper?  Mrs. Everly, you old bat, I know it's you!

speaker: Daphne
text: Yoo-hoo?  It's right here, we brought it in for you.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to outside world_] Sorry, sorry. [_closes door and examines paper_] Oh, wait a minute, this...  where's the rubber band? This paper has been read.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well don't worry, we won't tell you what's in it.

speaker: Frasier
text: That is not the point.  Dad, dad?  Come and sit down please, would you?

speaker: Daphne
text: You're going to give a speech, aren't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that's right, I forgot, you're psychic.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes, but I think anyone could feel this one coming on.

speaker: Frasier
text: Let us get something clear.  I am not a morning person.  I have to ease into my day slowly.  First I have my coffee - sans eggshells or anything else one tends to pick out of the garbage. Then I have a low-fat, high-fiber breakfast.  Finally I sit down and read a crisp, new newspaper.  If I am robbed of the richness of my morning routine, I cannot function.  My radio show suffers, and like ripples in a pond, so do the many listeners that rely on my advise, to help them through their troubled lives.  I'm sorry if this may sound priggish, but I have grown comfortable with this part of myself.  It is the magic that is me.

speaker: Martin
text: [_to Daphne, while exiting to the kitchen_] Get used to it.

speaker: Daphne
text: I know this is a stressful time, and this is new for all of us, but I'm sure that soon we'll all be getting along swimmingly. [_looks down at Frasier's robe_] Ooh, six more weeks of winter, I see.  _Frasier closes his robe.  He sits at the table and starts reading the paper.  Eddie comes over and jumps onto a chair to stare at him._

speaker: Frasier
text: Down Eddie, down. [_Eddie doesn't move_] I said down.  Good boy Eddie, just get down.  Good good, Eddie get down.  Eddie, GET DOWN! [_Eddie still just sits there, staring at Frasier_] Dad, dad, I can't read my paper, Eddie's staring at me.

speaker: Martin
text: Why, you do make quite a picture in the morning.  Just ignore him.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm trying to.

speaker: Martin
text: I was talking to the dog.  _Frasier goes back to his paper, holding it up to block Eddie's view. He slowly lifts it far enough to see Eddie still staring at him.  He gives up and walks towards his private bathroom.  Eddie follows._

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't even think about it! [_he leaves, Eddie follows_]  _FADE OUT  Scene B: KACL Frasier is doing his show._

speaker: Frasier
text: You're listening to Dr. Frasier Crane.  Our topic today is... intrusion.  Those who encroach on our sense of personal space. The neighbor who plays his stereo too loud.  The person who sits next to you in the movie theater when there are fifty other vacant seats.  Now let's return to our calls, and let me remind you once more, that our topic today is intrusion, since so many of you seem to be forgetting that.

speaker: Roz
text: Dr. Crane, we have Leonard from Everett, on line two.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello Leonard, I'm listening.

speaker: Leonard
text: [_v.o._] Oh, hi Dr. Crane.  Ah, I'm a little nervous, but ah... well, here goes.  Several years ago I became afraid of large, open spaces.  Like, if I went to the mall, I'd break out in a cold sweat, I'd get so scared that I'd have to run home.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes Leonard, and your comments on intrusion?

speaker: Leonard
text: Nothing.  Just that, now I'm afraid to go outside at all. I haven't seen another person in eight months.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well Leonard, it sounds like you may have a very serious condition known as agoraphobia.  But you're not alone.

speaker: Leonard
text: But I am alone, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen Leonard, I'm afraid your problem is too difficult to deal with in the time we have remaining, so if you stay on the line, someone will give you the name of a qualified therapist.  Well, that's all the time we have for today. You've been listening to Dr. Frasier Crane, KACL 780. Stay tuned for the news.  Then next up, Bob "Bulldog" Briscoe and the Gonzo Sports Show.  I never miss it. [_off air_] Yeah, right.

speaker: Roz
text: You want your messages?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, listen Roz, just hang on to them.  I think I'll stay in here for a while.  Today more than most, I feel an overwhelming need for solitude.  I've got a fascinating book here, a comfortable chair and a soundproof booth.  _Just as Frasier leans back and opens his book the door opens and Bulldog walks in pushing his props trolley._

speaker: Bulldog
text: Hiya, doc.  How're they hangin'?

speaker: Frasier
text: Bulldog, what are you doing here?

speaker: Bulldog
text: We lost transmitter link power in Studio C.  I gotta do my show from here.  _He bangs the gong and blows his whistle, indicating Frasier should leave._

speaker: Bulldog
text: Hey, where the hell's my Cosell tape?  Somebody stole my Cosell tape! THIS STINKS!  THIS IS TOTAL B.S.!  THIS... oh, here it is.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_preparing to leave_] Let me just get out of your way.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Oh, by the way doc, doc, I heard what you said to that kid who fantasizes about killing his parents?  You know what I would have told him?  Sports.  You go out there, break some heads- [_hits himself on the head to illustrate_] That'll turn him around.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  If only Jeffrey Dahmer had picked up a squash racquet. [_goes into Roz's booth_]

speaker: Bulldog
text: Hey, where the hell's my Lasorda tape?  THIS IS TOT... ah, got it.

speaker: Roz
text: [_to Frasier, as he starts to exit into the corridor_] Hold on a second, I have to ask you something. [_into phone_] Gary?  I broke up with him three weeks ago.  The sex was okay, but he was kinda limited. [_Frasier moves to leave, Roz stops him_] No, no. [_into phone_] It wasn't that Gary was bad in bed.  I mean, he knew where all the parts were.  Unfortunately, most of them were his.  Yes, totally passionless, it was like he was thinking of someone else.  I know I was.  Somebody's here, I gotta go. Alright?  Talk to you later.  Bye, mom. [_hangs up_]

speaker: Frasier
text: That was your mother?

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah, why?

speaker: Frasier
text: You talk to your mother like that?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, we're both adults.  We talk about everything.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, isn't that healthy.

speaker: Roz
text: What, you don't talk to your dad like that?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, hardly.  We hardly speak at all.

speaker: Roz
text: Really?

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah yes, well you know, we're just not really similar people. In fact, my brother and I are a lot more like my mother. You know, if it wasn't biologically impossible I'd swear that dad was dropped in a basket on our doorstep.

speaker: Bulldog
text: [_from other booth_] Hey sweetcakes, you seen my engineer?

speaker: Roz
text: I think someone's talking to you, Frasier.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Come on, come on, come on!

speaker: Roz
text: [_into mike_] Yes, he called, he'll be right here. [_to Frasier_] So do you want to go across the street and have one of those expensive coffee drinks?

speaker: Frasier
text: Maybe some other time.  Right now, I'd like to continue my quest for solitude.  I'll go somewhere where my father, Mary Poppins and the hound from hell can't find me.  I think maybe I'll just go sit under the shade of a tree and read in a quiet park. [_exits_] **THE BEST LAID PLANS...**  [_Over the screen we hear the sounds of a thunderstorm._]  _Scene C: Frasier's Apartment. He enters._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello. [_realises the room in empty_] Hello?  Dad?  Daphne?  Eddie? [_takes off coat; to himself_] Could it be?  _He arranges his book on the couch and pours himself a drink whilst humming the Toreador song from "Carmen."_

speaker: Frasier
text: Toreador, Don't spit on the floor, Use the cuspidor-a What do you think it's for-a?  _Drink in hand, he relaxes into the couch and starts reading. Within seconds, the door opens._

speaker: Daphne
text: [_to Martin_]...so the elephant says, "He's with me." [_they both laugh_] Oh, Dr. Crane, you're home.  We just got back from your father's physical therapy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, glory be.  Oh, happy day.  Not that I'm not delighted to see the two of you, it's just that I'm in the middle of a very exciting chapter.

speaker: Daphne
text: Ooh, I understand.  So why don't I pop into the kitchen and brew you up a nice pot of tea?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I just poured myself a glass of wine, thank you.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_pointedly looking at watch_] I see. [_leaves_]

speaker: Martin
text: [_sitting in the Chair_] Whatcha reading?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh dad, you wouldn't find it very interesting.

speaker: Martin
text: I might.  Any good?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I haven't formed a opinion yet.  Oddly enough, I'm having a little trouble getting into it.

speaker: Martin
text: [_after a moment's silence, indicates book_] Thick.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad will you... Listen, I don't want to offend, but if you wouldn't mind, could you just leave me alone, let me read my book?

speaker: Martin
text: No problem.  _Martin sits quietly, not looking as Frasier reads.  This finally irks Frasier._

speaker: Frasier
text: What are you doing?

speaker: Martin
text: I'm leaving you alone.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it's very annoying!

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, what's your problem?  You've been sucking a lemon all week.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, all right, I'll tell you what my problem is, I can't get a moment's peace alone in my own house.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, forgive me.  When you invited me to move in I didn't realise I had to stay chained to the radiator in my room [_starts to leave_]

speaker: Frasier
text: [_quietly_] Perhaps only evenings.

speaker: Martin
text: I heard that!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, of course you heard it, you're never out of earshot!

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, you know, you've always been like this.  You were always a fussy little kid, and it's gotten worse ever since.  You and your precious morning routine.  You gotta have your coffee, you gotta have your quiet, you gotta have this, you gotta have that. Well, aren't you the little hothouse orchid.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hey, hey-hey-hey!  I don't have to sit here and listen to that!

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, if you want everything so perfect, why don't you go live in a bubble?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh right, oh well, right now it sounds very inviting!

speaker: Martin
text: [_sitting down again_] Finally, a little peace and quiet around here.  _End of Act One.  Act Two.  Scene A: Cafe Nervosa. Frasier is sitting, reading his book as Niles walks in._

speaker: Niles
text: Hello there, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, what fresh hell is this?

speaker: Niles
text: That's a nice way to greet your brother. [_to waiter_] Cafe latte, _per piachere._

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, Niles, it's just I've been trying to read this book and it seems no matter where I alight I get interrupted.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, "The Holotropic Mind" by Stanislav Grolf.  I love his conclusion that a change in breathing patterns can induce alternate states of consciousness.

speaker: Frasier
text: Great. [_slams book shut_] Now you've ruined the ending!

speaker: Niles
text: I'm sorry, that was inconsiderate. [_the waiter brings his coffee_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Father?  You mean the man who's driving me crazy?  The man who makes me dread the sight of my very doorstep?  The man who just drove me out of my own home?

speaker: Niles
text: And how's work?

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I don't know what I'm going to do.  Dad and I had another fight.  I'm afraid if we stay under the same roof together we'll do irreparable harm to the relationship we have as it is.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, what are the alternatives?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, if I didn't feel so guilty I'd, I'd do what I should have done in the first place: just move dad and Daphne into their own apartment.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, for goodness sake, Frasier.  It hasn't been that long, you have to give it a chance.  And you might remember why you moved him in in the first place.

speaker: Frasier
text: Refresh me.

speaker: Niles
text: You wanted to get closer to dad.

speaker: Frasier
text: I still do.  There isn't anything I'd like more, but he makes it impossible.  I can't read my book, I can't have my coffee, I can't have any peace in my own home.

speaker: Niles
text: So what you're saying is, you want to be closer to dad, but you don't actually want him around.  Ask yourself Frasier, have you tried to sit down and talk to him - I mean, really talk to him?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I... [_he thinks about it_] Maybe I haven't done my best. I guess I owe that to the old man, don't I?  Well ah, thanks for the chat, Niles.  You're a good brother, and a credit to the psychiatric profession.

speaker: Niles
text: You're a good brother too.   **A COUPLE OF WHITE GUYS SITTIN' 'ROUND TALKIN'**  _Scene B: Frasier's Apartment. He arrives to find some of his furniture piled up beside the door._

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne? What are my things doing here?  My leather wing chair? My Kusami lamp?

speaker: Daphne
text: [_entering from back, carrying a box_] We're putting them in the storage room, in the basement.  There was no room for them in the study once we got my furniture in.  We discussed it last night, remember?

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course, of course.

speaker: Daphne
text: I was just on my way to ask that peculiar little man from building services to give me a hand moving them.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh yes, Kyle.  Well, give him my regards.

speaker: Daphne
text: Remind me again - which one of Kyle's eyes is really looking at me?

speaker: Frasier
text: The brown one.

speaker: Martin
text: Daphne left your dinner in the fridge, if you're hungry.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well thanks, but I'm not.  Ah... Dad, I'm sorry about the blow-up earlier.

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, forget about it.  I already have.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, I guess there's no secret that there's been a lot of tension between us, and I think maybe one of the reasons is that we never have a chance to sit down and talk.  And I... I thought we might have a conversation.

speaker: Martin
text: Right now?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I think now would be a good time.

speaker: Martin
text: Later would be better.

speaker: Frasier
text: It doesn't have to be a long, drawn-out conversation, I'm talking about three minutes of your life.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I hope it is only three minutes, 'cause my program's coming on.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, alright.  If it'll make you any happier I will get the egg-timer and I will set it for three minutes.

speaker: Martin
text: So what do you want to talk about?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, the idea is for us to have a normal, honest conversation like two normal people without getting on each other's nerves. Ready? [_sets timer_] Go.

speaker: Martin
text: This is stupid.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_stops timer_] One second?  That's our personal best?  Let us see if we can beat it. [_sets timer_] Ready?  Go.

speaker: Martin
text: So how about those Seahawks?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_stops timer_] No sports.

speaker: Martin
text: All right.  But no opera.

speaker: Frasier
text: Agreed. [_sets timer_] Ready?  Go.

speaker: Martin
text: [_pause_] This is your idea, you say something first.

speaker: Frasier
text: Alright, alright.  I'll, I'll tell you something about myself that ah, that you don't know.  Ah, six months ago, when Lilith and I were really on the rocks, ah, there was a time of depression I went through that was so terrible I actually climbed out on a ledge and wondered if life was worth living. I... And then I thought of Frederick.

speaker: Martin
text: And you didn't jump, huh?

speaker: Frasier
text: Good, dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Wow.  I never knew that.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that's the point of this whole experiment.  To tell one another something that we don't know about each other.  Something vulnerable.  Now it's your turn.

speaker: Martin
text: Okay. [_thinks_] Well, about two months ago, I was in the basement, going through some old pictures of your mother and me... and all of a sudden something flew up in my eye.  And, when I was trying to get it out, I realised I could turn my eyelid inside out, the way kids do at camp.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's it?  You call that vulnerable?

speaker: Martin
text: It hurt.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh well... I'm not talking about that kind of pain, I'm talking about your emotions, your soul.  Some sort of painful, gut- wrenching experience.

speaker: Martin
text: Other than this one?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, God!  Always the flip answer.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, this whole thing's stupid.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, not to me.  Oh, how should I expect anything out of you? You are the most cold, intractable, unapproachable, distant, stubborn, cold man I've ever known!

speaker: Martin
text: You said "cold" twice, Mr. Egghead.

speaker: Frasier
text: Egghead?  Egghead?

speaker: Martin
text: You said "egghead" twice, too.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, you are so infuriating!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you're no day at the beach either.  You know what you are? [_the timer bings_] I'll tell you later, it's time for my program. [_moves towards Chair_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, I don't think you see how serious this is.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, will you give it a rest?

speaker: Frasier
text: We're not getting along, and it's not getting any better.  I'm not sure how to say this, but ah... I ah, I'm afraid I'm gonna have to...

speaker: Martin
text: I know what you're trying to say.  "You want what's best for both of us."  You want to get me out of here, then you can have your own space, and I'll have my own space, and we can put an end to all this bickering.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, yes.  I guess it wasn't so hard to say after all.

speaker: Martin
text: Except for one thing.  I'm not going.

speaker: Frasier
text: What?

speaker: Martin
text: Look, you want us to forge some great father-son relationship, to make some connection.  Well, that kind of thing takes a couple of years, not a couple of days, doesn't it?  You're the shrink.

speaker: Frasier
text: Couple of years, huh?

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, it'll go by before you know it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Either that, or it'll seem like eternity.

speaker: Martin
text: I'm willing to give it a shot if you are.

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay.

speaker: Martin
text: Great.  How about you and me having a beer together?

speaker: Frasier
text: Wow.  You know, in all these years you've never asked me that. I'd love to have a beer with you, dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Well then, you better haul ass, 'cause the store closes in ten minutes.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right. [_exits_]   **ONE MAN 'S STORAGE ROOM IS ANOTHER MAN'S SANCTUARY**
